history.content:
The majority of the material taught in lectures is very high level: how to interview, how to critique, brainstorm, improve your designs, interview and observe people as research for a project, etc (most of which is common sense, but that's just my opinion). There's only a couple lectures on design principles/typography/colors and they're not that in depth. There were zero lectures related to programming, but the projects are very coding intensive (i.e. lots and lots and lots of reading stack overflow and android developers guide). Basically you'll end up teaching yourself pretty much everything you learn about mobile dev, but I did learn a lot I suppose. Apparently next semester they might stop doing android watch development and just do mobile, which will eliminate some coding headaches.

In short, it's intended to focus on the process of designing products for users, not the technical programming aspects. The midterm was almost entirely short answer questions about vocabulary terms, identifying design principles, procedures for interviews and critiques, sketching app interface screens.

children.subject:
Not student answer anon, but current head 160 TA. +1 to their answer.

Take 160 if you want to make a cool final project/portfolio piece and are interested in the UI/UX/Product design industry. Discussion touches on Android code to get you started but we do expect most of the programming learning to be on your own, since we focus on design. Alternatively, you can come to our public showcase this semester and see for yourself :) It's Weds May 4th (during dead week) from 12-130 and 2-330 in 310 Jacobs.
Cool, thanks for the info Jingyi! Does the 160 curriculum plan on staying the same (focused on Android Wear) for future iterations of the class?
I have no idea...it really depends on who's teaching it, and currently that's still in the air.
Ok! Do the design principles taught extend beyond Android wear though?
Yes, definitely! In fact I'd say Android wear design principles is basically just half a section's worth of material :P
Thank you, I look forward to taking this class sometime in the future :)
(not OP) Awesome answer! Anyone else have anything to add?

history.content: Looking at the slides, it seems more like a project management class than a technical class. What exactly do we actually learn in the class, can somebody who's taken it comment?
history.subject: CS 160
